preReadQuiz.description: Take this quiz to test your understanding of React Hooks!

questions.description: Which of the following scenarios describe a correct usage of the useState Hook? Check all that apply.
questions.explanation: One of the core rules of React Hooks is that they should be called the same number of times between renders of a component. If a hook needs to not apply its logic if some condition is true or false, that logic should live within the hook itself (and not above it.) Class Components are not compatible with Hooks, and will cause a runtime error.

choices.value: Calling useState from within a Class Component
Calling useState from within a Function Component
Calling useState from within an if/else statement
Calling useState from within a forEach statement on an array whose length can change

questions.description: Which of the following snippets of code represent a valid implementation of useState that allows the button to function?
questions.explanation: Snippet 1 will result in a JavaScript syntax error. Snippet 2, while not incorrect, does not provide an initial value to 'useState', which will produce an initial value of 'count' as 'undefined'. When trying to increment the value in 'handleButtonClick', incrementing 'count' by one will return 'NaN'. Snippet 3 is missing an array destructuring statement, and Snippet 5 attempts to import the functionality of useState as if it could be imported, when instead it must be array-destructured.

questions.description: True or False - React Hooks give you permission to refactor all of your Class Components to be Hooked Components.
questions.explanation: React Hooks are best implemented in new code, or to move away from unsafe/unstable patterns. Class Components are still 100% valid, and the time invested in refactoring old code is better spent in writing new code with Hooks.

questions.description: When you return a function from within a useEffect call, when does this function get executed?
questions.explanation: The function returned by useEffect is executed only when the component unmounts.

choices.value: When the component's children are mounted
When the component throws an error
